Fathendayin, Translated by Imperial Order Thus have I heard.
At one time, the Blessed One.
Was in RÄjagá¹›ha.
At that time, the Venerable RÄhula.
Was wandering in the Chiyaka Yatanta land of the Cold Forest.
In the midst of a large mound.
At that time, there were celestial spirits, dragon spirits, yaká¹£as, rÄká¹£asas, kiá¹ƒnaras, and mahoragas.
And all other kinds of humans and non-humans.
Hungry ghosts, bhÅ«tas, piÅ›Äcas, and kuá¹£mÄá¹‡á¸as came to possess them.
There were also many different kinds of crows, magpies.
Foxes, jackals, wolves, insects, and ants.
They were extremely disturbed.
At that time, the Venerable RÄhula went to where the Buddha was.
Having arrived, he touched his head to the ground.
He bowed at the World-Honored One's feet and circumambulated him three times.
Standing before the World-Honored One, weeping and crying piteously.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to Rahula:
Why are you now weeping and crying, standing before me?
Rahula said: It is like this, World-Honored One.
I was previously staying in the city of Rajagriha, in the cold forest of the womb-deceiving Gaya region.
In a large mound.
At that time, there were celestial ghosts, dragon ghosts, yakshas, rakshasas, kinnaras, mahoragas,
and all other kinds of human and non-human beings.
Hungry ghosts, putanas, pisacas, and ghouls, etc.
All came to possess me.
There were also many different kinds of birds, magpies, foxes, jackals, wolves, and insects, etc.
Extremely disturbing me.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to the Venerable Rahula:
Rahula, listen attentively now. There is this great secret and difficult to subdue dharani.
To protect the assembly of listeners.

118. Tene 119. Vishtene 120. Sangkhe 121. Sangkhe 122. Sangche 123. Sangche 124. Sadodaru 125. Minu minu hara hara 126. Mandumati 127. Hirihiri 128. Kilikili garale 129. Huru huru 130. Bhagele 131. Namaá¸¥ siddha-buddha-bhagavate svÄhÄ 132. Furthermore, RÄhula,
for those who recite this great mantra dhÄraá¹‡Ä«,
One can make offerings with incense and flowers.
And form mudras, recite the mantra with utmost sincerity one hundred and eight times, tie various strings on one's hands and neck.
One will then be able to provide protection all around for a hundred yojanas.
Humans and non-humans will all stay far away.
One will also not be burned by water or fire, harmed by swords, sticks, poison, or medicine, or afflicted by malaria or epidemic diseases.
They will not be able to invade or harm, nor will one die an untimely death. The diseases of VetÄla and the bright mantras
By reciting this mantra, one will all attain peace and happiness.
If one is bound by others, one will be immediately liberated from all calamities and afflictions.
It is said that disputes and arguments will also be completely eliminated.
If there are ghosts and spirits that come to cause disturbances and do not retreat,
One should simply recite this mantra with utmost sincerity.
Those ghosts and spirits will see the mantra-reciting person
Like the great yaká¹£a lord VajrapÄá¹‡i, pure and single-minded in vajra,
Fierce and majestic, with blazing flames.
The Four Heavenly Kings each hold an iron wheel.
Sharp swords will chase them away and scatter them.
Their heads will be split into seven pieces and their bodies will be torn apart.
If those ghosts and spirits return to their original abodes,
those of the same kind will not allow them to join the assembly.
They will also not be allowed to reside in the great king's capital city of Aá¹­akavati.
Furthermore, RÄhula, if one sincerely recites and upholds this Nandin MahÄvidyÄ DhÄraá¹‡Ä«,
one will be able to stay far away from kings, thieves, water, fire, poisonous vapors, and weapons.
In desolate mountains, forests, dangerous paths, and evil roads,
those who come and go will have no fear at all.
Furthermore, RÄhula,
this Nandin MahÄvidyÄ DhÄraá¹‡Ä«ğŸ”½has been, is being, and will be spoken by the Buddhas,
who are as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River.
They are fully endowed with spiritual powers.
Those with great spiritual powers, such as devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, and mahoragas,
are surrounded and worshiped by all beings.
Those beings, free from all fears, all attain happiness.
At that time, the Venerable RÄhula and the great assembly, having heard the World-Honored One's teaching, single-mindedly believed and accepted it. They bowed to the Buddha and withdrew.
